narrative_arc: Workflow broken → AI automates it → proven ROI → massive market → defensible moat

failure_patterns.pattern: Adding AI to a step without owning the workflow
failure_patterns.why_fatal: You become a feature, not a product. The workflow owner (Salesforce, HubSpot, etc.) will add your feature.
failure_patterns.early_warning: "We integrate with X to do Y" where X owns the customer. No standalone value without the integration.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Own the workflow end-to-end. If you automate CRM updates, own the whole sales workflow, not just data entry.

failure_patterns.pattern: Product impresses in demos but doesn't deliver in daily use
failure_patterns.why_fatal: High churn. Customers buy the vision but leave when reality doesn't match.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Great demo-to-trial conversion, poor trial-to-paid. Customers say "cool" but don't use daily. NPS drops after month 1.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Optimize for daily habit, not demo wow. Measure DAU/MAU. Build for the boring use case, not the impressive one.

failure_patterns.pattern: "AI for sales/marketing/ops" without vertical focus
failure_patterns.why_fatal: You compete with everyone. No differentiated story. Can't hire domain experts.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Website says "AI for [broad category]". Sales conversations are all over the map. Different customers have different use cases.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Pick one vertical or one use case. "AI for RevOps at B2B SaaS companies" beats "AI for sales".

failure_patterns.pattern: Hiring sales team before product-market fit
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Sales can't sell what doesn't stick. You burn cash and blame the sales team.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Founder closes deals, reps can't. Churn is high. Customers need heavy customization.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Founder sells first 20 customers. Hire first AE only when you can hand them a playbook that works.

failure_patterns.pattern: AI product that doesn't get better with more customers
failure_patterns.why_fatal: No compounding advantage. Competitors catch up.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Model performance is same for 10 users vs 1000. No proprietary data collection. Using same foundation model as everyone.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid:
Design for data collection from day one. Fine-tune on customer data (with permission). Build feedback loops that improve accuracy.

success_stories.archetype: Deep vertical focus, expand within vertical
success_stories.pattern: One workflow for one buyer → expand to adjacent workflows
key_moves: Started with one workflow (contract review for legal teams)
Got deep: integrations, templates, compliance features legal needs
Expanded to adjacent (contract negotiation, obligation tracking)
Became the platform for that workflow
success_stories.outcome_signal: Net retention >150%. Competitors couldn't match depth. Expansion revenue 2x new business.

success_stories.pattern: Free/cheap entry → usage grows → team adoption → enterprise deal
key_moves: Started with free tier for individuals
Built for viral adoption (team features, shared workspaces)
Usage triggered sales outreach at threshold
Converted active teams to enterprise deals
success_stories.outcome_signal: $0 CAC for initial adoption. 60% of enterprise deals started as free users.

success_stories.archetype: Replace entire manual process, not augment
success_stories.pattern: Find 10-hour/week manual task → automate to 1 hour → charge 10% of time saved
key_moves: Found CFOs spending 3 days/month on close
Priced at value delivered ($2K/month vs $10K in labor)
success_stories.outcome_signal:
3-week sales cycles. CFOs became champions. High expansion (more entities, more workflows).

gtm_patterns.timeline: 3-6 months to launch integration. 6-12 months to see volume.

investor_questions.question: What workflow do you replace?
investor_questions.good_answer: Finance teams spend 8 hours/week reconciling expenses across 4 systems. We automate it to 30 minutes with AI-powered matching and exception flagging.
investor_questions.bad_answer: We help companies with their data.
investor_questions.follow_up: Can you show me before/after with a real customer?

investor_questions.question: Why is AI necessary here?
investor_questions.good_answer: Rules can't handle 40K expense categories and natural language descriptions. Our model learns each company's coding patterns and gets to 95% accuracy by month 2.
investor_questions.follow_up: Could this be done with rules or heuristics?

investor_questions.question: Who's your ICP?
investor_questions.good_answer: CFOs at 100-500 employee B2B SaaS companies growing >50% YoY. They have 2-3 person finance teams drowning in manual work.
investor_questions.follow_up: Who are your best 3 customers and what do they have in common?

investor_questions.question: What's your net retention?
investor_questions.good_answer: 125% at month 6. Expansion from additional seats (+40%) and new modules (+60%). Churn is 2% monthly.
investor_questions.follow_up: How do you know customers are getting value over time?

investor_questions.question: Why do customers churn?
investor_questions.good_answer: 80% of churn is company-level (shutdowns, M&A). 20% is product gaps we're fixing—we lost 3 customers who needed multi-currency we're shipping in Q2.
investor_questions.follow_up: Can I talk to a customer who churned?

investor_questions.question: Why won't Salesforce/HubSpot/etc. just build this?
investor_questions.good_answer: They're optimizing for breadth. We go deep on RevOps for B2B SaaS—14 integrations, custom objects, comp plans. They'd need 18 months and a dedicated team. It's not their priority.
investor_questions.follow_up: What's your moat in 24 months?

narrative_arc: Content demand explosion → AI-powered creation at scale → performance-driven optimization → sustainable content engine

failure_patterns.pattern: Content flagged as AI-generated hurts brand credibility
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Audiences and search engines increasingly detect/penalize AI content. "AI slop" backlash is real.
failure_patterns.early_warning: SEO traffic drops. Audience engagement declining. "This reads like AI" feedback. Content flagged by detection tools.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Human-in-the-loop for all published content. Unique data and insights. AI assists, doesn't write. Focus on ideation and optimization, not generation.

failure_patterns.pattern: Producing more content without improving performance
failure_patterns.why_fatal: More mediocre content ≠ better results. Actually hurts brand and SEO.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Content volume up but engagement flat/down. "We're posting more but not seeing results." CPE (cost per engagement) rising.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Measure content performance religiously. Quality gates before publishing. Kill underperforming content types. Less but better.

failure_patterns.pattern: Building for channel that becomes commoditized
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Platforms change algorithms, add native AI tools. Channel-specific tools become obsolete.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Platform announces native AI features. Channel algorithm changes hurt performance. Competitor launches free alternative.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Multi-channel from early on. Build brand-specific value (voice, data). Don't depend on single platform.

failure_patterns.pattern: Selling efficiency to agencies who bill by hour
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Agencies make money on hours worked. Tool that reduces hours reduces their revenue.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Agencies try but don't expand. "This would put our writers out of work." Agencies hide tool from clients.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Help agencies win more clients (capacity), not reduce hours. Quality improvement > time reduction. Or sell direct to brands.

failure_patterns.pattern: Generic content that doesn't match brand voice
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Brands spend millions on voice and positioning. Off-brand content is worse than no content.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Every brand's content sounds the same. Clients heavily edit output. "Doesn't sound like us" feedback.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid:
Train on brand-specific content. Style guides and brand voice profiles. Human review for brand alignment.

success_stories.pattern: Search data → content gaps → optimized content → rankings
success_stories.outcome_signal: Clear SEO lift. Clients couldn't do content strategy without data.

success_stories.pattern: Core content → channel adaptation → distribution → measurement
key_moves: Create once, adapt for every channel
success_stories.outcome_signal: 5x content output, same team. Brands consolidated tools onto platform.

success_stories.archetype: Content that converts, measured and optimized
success_stories.pattern: Brief → creation → testing → optimization → scale winners
success_stories.outcome_signal:
Clear conversion lift. Content tied directly to revenue.

investor_questions.question: How do you handle AI content detection concerns?
investor_questions.good_answer: We don't generate final content—we enhance human work. AI handles research, outlines, optimization suggestions. Humans write and approve. Our content passes all detection tools because it is human-written, just AI-assisted. We also train on brand-specific data, creating unique voice.
investor_questions.bad_answer: AI detection tools aren't that good.
investor_questions.follow_up: What happens if Google starts penalizing AI content?

investor_questions.question: How do you maintain brand voice across clients?
investor_questions.good_answer: Brand voice profile for every client: tone, vocabulary, style guide, 50+ example pieces. AI trained on their specific content. Every piece reviewed against brand voice score. 92% of content passes brand review without revisions.
investor_questions.follow_up: Can you show how two different brands' content would differ?

investor_questions.question: Does content actually perform better?
investor_questions.good_answer: Average 45% increase in organic traffic within 6 months. 35% higher engagement rate than pre-platform content. We A/B test everything—only scale what works. Clients see direct correlation: more content + better optimization = more traffic and conversions.
investor_questions.follow_up: Can you show before/after performance metrics for a real client?

investor_questions.question: What's your retention like?
investor_questions.good_answer: 88% annual retention. Net retention 118%—clients expand channels and volume. Main churn: companies that cut marketing budget entirely. When clients leave, 40% come back within 12 months.
investor_questions.follow_up: What's your 12-month cohort retention?

narrative_arc: Engagement overload → AI automates quality responses → measurable engagement lift → data moat

failure_patterns.pattern: Business depends entirely on one platform's API
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Platforms change APIs, restrict access, or build competing features. You have no leverage.
failure_patterns.early_warning: 90%+ of value requires specific platform API. No backup plan if access changes. Platform announcements surprise you.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Multi-platform from day one. Build platform-agnostic core value. Maintain relationships with platform partner teams.

failure_patterns.pattern: AI responds fast but poorly
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Bad responses damage brand reputation. Customers turn it off after one embarrassing post.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Customers manually review every AI response. Examples of awkward AI replies. Quality settings maxed to "human review."
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Quality over speed. Confidence scores. Human-in-the-loop for brand-sensitive responses. Train on brand voice.

failure_patterns.pattern: High activity metrics, no business impact
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Brands pay for business outcomes (leads, sales, retention), not vanity metrics.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Reporting focuses on "posts published" not conversions. Customers ask "but did we sell more?" Can't tie engagement to revenue.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Connect engagement to business outcomes. Attribution to conversions. Report on metrics that matter to CFO.

failure_patterns.pattern: Underestimating enterprise social media workflows
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Enterprise has approval workflows, compliance review, legal hold, multi-brand management. Consumer tools don't work.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Enterprise pilots stall at "workflow requirements." Compliance team blocks deployment. "We need approval routing."
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Build enterprise features early: approval workflows, audit trails, role permissions, compliance integration.

failure_patterns.pattern: Building feature Hootsuite/Sprinklr will add
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Incumbent social tools invest heavily. Point features get absorbed.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Your value is one capability. Incumbents announce similar feature. "Why not just use Sprinklr?"
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid:
Own a workflow completely. Build data moat from interactions. Go vertical (hospitality social, healthcare social).

narrative_arc: Evolving threat → AI detects what rules miss → compliance built-in → massive cost of inaction

failure_patterns.pattern: Point solution that enterprise security stack will absorb
failure_patterns.why_fatal: CrowdStrike, Palo Alto, Microsoft will add your feature. You get acquired cheap or die.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Your differentiation is one detection type. Enterprise evaluates you as "nice to have." Platform vendors announce similar capability.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Own a security domain completely. Build platform with multiple detection types. Create data moat from deployment scale.

failure_patterns.pattern: Great detection, terrible precision
failure_patterns.why_fatal: SOC teams drown in alerts. They'll turn you off. One noisy tool ruins your reputation.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Customers ask to reduce alert sensitivity. SOC analysts complain about alert fatigue. Detection rate marketed more than precision.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Optimize for precision as much as recall. Publish false positive rate alongside detection rate. Build tuning capabilities for customer environments.

failure_patterns.pattern: Claiming compliance support without real depth
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Enterprises audit. If you fail compliance audit, you're out. Compliance is table stakes, not differentiator.
failure_patterns.early_warning: "We support SOC 2" but no audit report. Compliance mentioned on website but not in product. No compliance team.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Get SOC 2 Type II before selling to enterprise. Support compliance reporting in product. Hire compliance specialist.

failure_patterns.pattern: Detection works in lab, fails in production
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Security products are judged by real-world performance. One miss = lost trust forever.
failure_patterns.early_warning: All demos use synthetic data. No production deployment testimonials. "Results may vary" disclaimers.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid:
Validate on real enterprise data (anonymized if needed). Publish real-world detection rates. Get production testimonials.

narrative_arc: Unit economics pressure → AI improves per-order metrics → scales with GMV → data flywheel

failure_patterns.pattern: Building optimization Shopify/Amazon will obviously add
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Platforms invest billions in merchant success. Core optimization features get added to platform.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Your feature is one API call. Platform has beta of similar feature. "Better than native" is your pitch.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Go deep on vertical (fashion, food, DTC). Build data moat platforms can't replicate. Own workflow, not feature.

failure_patterns.pattern: Showing AI potential, not actual merchant results
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Merchants care about their P&L. "Potential 20% lift" means nothing without proof.
failure_patterns.early_warning: All demos use synthetic data. No A/B test results. "Results may vary" on everything.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: A/B test everything. Measure actual lift, not predicted. Case studies with real merchant numbers.

failure_patterns.pattern: Serving SMB merchants with high-touch product
failure_patterns.why_fatal: SMB merchants have low willingness to pay ($50-200/mo). If product needs support, economics fail.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Support costs exceed revenue per merchant. Need sales call for $100/mo customer. High churn from businesses failing.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Self-serve or bust for SMB. Or go upmarket to enterprise. Don't get stuck in middle.

failure_patterns.pattern: Claiming to reduce returns without measurement
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Returns are complex. Many factors beyond your control. Hard to prove causation.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Can't isolate your impact from other factors. Merchants can't measure return reduction. "Returns improved" without data.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Controlled experiments. Isolate your variable. Conservative claims. Focus on metrics you can clearly prove.

failure_patterns.pattern: Improving AOV while hurting conversion (or vice versa)
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Metrics are connected. Win on one, lose on another = net zero. Merchants see through it.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Headline metric improves but revenue doesn't. Merchants report unintended consequences. Cherry-picking metrics.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid:
Track holistic impact. Revenue per visitor matters more than any single metric. Report trade-offs honestly.

failure_patterns.pattern: Product designed for students but teachers hate it
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Teachers gate classroom time. If they don't assign it, students won't use it.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Teachers call it "extra work." Product doesn't fit lesson plans. No teacher dashboard or controls.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Design for teacher workflow first. Reduce teacher prep time. Align to standards and existing curriculum.

failure_patterns.pattern: Students engage but don't learn more
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Parents and districts pay for outcomes, not engagement. Gamification without learning is entertainment.
failure_patterns.early_warning: High engagement, flat test scores. No correlation between usage and outcomes. "Feels like a game."
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Build for learning outcomes, measure learning outcomes. Engagement is means, not end.

failure_patterns.pattern: Teachers love it but district won't buy
failure_patterns.why_fatal: K-12 procurement cycles are 12-18 months. You run out of money waiting.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Many teacher signups, no district deals. "We love it but don't have budget." "Talk to us next budget cycle."
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Understand procurement calendar (April-June for next year). Build relationship with district decision makers early. Offer pilots that align with budget cycles.

failure_patterns.pattern: Building without FERPA/COPPA understanding
failure_patterns.why_fatal: One compliance violation = banned from districts. Legal liability for student data.
failure_patterns.early_warning: No privacy policy. Collecting data without consent. No understanding of FERPA.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: FERPA/COPPA compliance from day one. Privacy by design. Hire compliance consultant before selling to districts.

failure_patterns.pattern: Marketing direct to parents/students in K-12
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Parents don't buy learning software. Districts do. B2C CAC is too high.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Paid social ads to parents. App store marketing. "Freemium for families."
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid:
B2B sales to districts. B2C only for tutoring/test prep where parents have budget. Consumer edtech needs $50M+ runway.

---

success_stories.pattern: Teacher pain → time savings → classroom adoption → district buy
key_moves: Solved teacher grading pain (4+ hours/week manual work)
Teachers demanded it at district level
Sold to districts on teacher retention and time savings
success_stories.outcome_signal: 80% teacher adoption (vs 20% for student-first tools). Teachers became champions.

success_stories.pattern: Research partnership → efficacy study → sales proof
key_moves: Partnered with university for RCT study
Used study in every sales conversation
success_stories.outcome_signal: Closed skeptical districts. Study became competitive moat.

success_stories.pattern: Standards alignment → teacher adoption → state approval
key_moves: Built directly to Common Core and state standards
Made adoption easy for teachers (no extra planning)
success_stories.outcome_signal:
State approval = sales velocity. Teachers didn't need to justify alignment.

investor_questions.follow_up: Engagement is great, but do they learn more?

investor_questions.question: Do teachers actually use it?
investor_questions.good_answer: 78% weekly teacher active rate. Teachers use 3.2x/week average. We reduce grading time by 4 hours/week, which teachers cite as #1 reason they use us.
investor_questions.follow_up: What's your weekly active rate for teachers?

investor_questions.question: How do you navigate district procurement?
investor_questions.good_answer: We start with free teacher pilots, build demand, then approach district. We're on 12 state-approved lists. Average procurement cycle is 8 months. We're in budget planning conversations in April.
investor_questions.bad_answer: Districts find us through our website.
investor_questions.follow_up: Have you closed a district deal yet?

investor_questions.question: How do you handle FERPA/COPPA?
investor_questions.good_answer: FERPA-compliant by design. We're iKeepSafe certified. We sign Data Privacy Agreements with every district. No student data sold or shared. Annual third-party privacy audit.
investor_questions.follow_up: Can you pass a district security review?

narrative_arc: Planning chaos → AI automates coordination → measurable event success → recurring lifecycle

failure_patterns.pattern: Revenue only when events happen
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Events are 1-3x/year per customer. 9 months of no revenue between. Cash flow dies.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Revenue spikes around event dates. No recurring subscription. "We charge per event."
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Build recurring value: year-round planning, attendee CRM, vendor management, analytics. Monthly subscription model.

failure_patterns.pattern: Building events business without cash planning
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Events are seasonal (spring/fall heavy). 3-4 months of low revenue can kill you.
failure_patterns.early_warning: All revenue in Q2 and Q4. No corporate/year-round events mix. No reserve for slow months.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Mix event types (corporate year-round + seasonal consumer). Build recurring revenue. Plan cash for 6 months of low season.

failure_patterns.pattern: Building single-user tool, not platform
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Single-user tools have low ACV and high churn. Platforms have network effects.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Only the organizer uses product. No vendor or attendee engagement. No data flowing between events.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Build for network: vendors, attendees, sponsors. Data from one event improves the next. Platform economics.

failure_patterns.pattern: Targeting event type without budget
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Small local events don't pay for software. Large events have complex procurement.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Customers love product but won't pay >$100/month. Average event budget is $5K.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Target events with real budget: corporate ($50K+), major conferences, high-end weddings. Or venue chains with volume.

failure_patterns.pattern: "AI plans your entire event"
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Events have high stakes. One AI mistake ruins wedding/conference. Organizers won't trust fully.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Customers don't trust AI recommendations. Manual override on everything. "AI suggested wrong vendor."
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid:
AI as assistant, not replacement. Build trust gradually. Human approval for major decisions. Confidence scores.

key_moves: Started with venue booking and calendar
Added full event management for venue clients
success_stories.outcome_signal: 95% venue retention. Expanded from booking to full ops.

success_stories.pattern: Meeting planning → full corporate events → enterprise
key_moves: Became default for Fortune 500 event teams
success_stories.outcome_signal: Enterprise contracts $50K+/year. Year-round usage (not seasonal).

success_stories.pattern: Vendor directory → marketplace → take rate
key_moves: Network effects: more vendors = more organizers
success_stories.outcome_signal:
Two-sided marketplace. 15% take rate. Network effects protect.

investor_questions.question: How do you handle seasonality?
investor_questions.good_answer: 60% of our customers are corporate events (year-round). We have monthly subscription, not per-event. Q1 is 70% of Q3 revenue, but still positive cash flow. We also added year-round features: vendor CRM, event portfolio analytics.
investor_questions.bad_answer: Events pick up in spring and fall.
investor_questions.follow_up: What's your revenue in January vs September?

investor_questions.question: Why would organizers trust AI?
investor_questions.good_answer: AI recommends, humans approve. Confidence scores on every recommendation. We started with low-risk (timeline suggestions), built trust, now do vendor recommendations. 85% of AI suggestions accepted.
investor_questions.follow_up: What's the worst AI mistake that happened?

investor_questions.question: Do organizers come back for the next event?
investor_questions.good_answer: 82% of organizers use us for their next event. Average customer manages 4.2 events/year with us. NRR is 118% from more events + more features.
investor_questions.bad_answer: We have a lot of events.
investor_questions.follow_up: What's your repeat usage rate?

investor_questions.question: What's the ROI for event organizers?
investor_questions.good_answer: Average 45% time savings in planning. For a $100K event, that's $8K in labor savings. We charge $500/month. 15x ROI. Plus better vendor pricing through our network.
investor_questions.follow_up: Can you quantify time or money saved?

narrative_arc: Creative chaos → AI-powered design & production → faster trend-to-market → sustainable scale

failure_patterns.pattern: Tech founders building design tools without fashion expertise
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Fashion has unwritten rules, taste hierarchies, and workflow nuances outsiders miss. Designers reject tools that feel "tech-bro."
failure_patterns.early_warning: Designers say "this isn't how we work." Product demos well but usage drops. Fashion advisors disagree with product direction.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Co-founder or early hire must be working designer. Embed with design teams. Build for workflow, not features.

failure_patterns.pattern: Claiming to predict fashion trends with AI
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Fashion trends are influenced by culture, celebrities, social movements—not just data patterns. Predictions are often wrong or obvious.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Predictions are vague ("florals for spring"). Can't show prediction accuracy. Competitors make same predictions.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Focus on trend detection (what's emerging now) not prediction. Provide data, not certainty. Help designers validate intuition, not replace it.

failure_patterns.pattern: Adding "sustainability" features without real impact
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Fashion brands are under intense scrutiny. False claims = PR disaster. Greenwashing backlash is severe.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Can't quantify environmental impact. Sustainability is marketing feature, not core product. No third-party verification.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Partner with sustainability certifiers. Measure actual impact (carbon, water, waste). Be honest about limitations.

failure_patterns.pattern: Building without understanding fashion calendar
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Fashion operates on seasons (Spring/Summer, Fall/Winter). Revenue and usage are highly cyclical. Wrong timing = missed market.
failure_patterns.early_warning: All revenue in Q1 and Q3. Dead periods surprise you. Customers say "we'll use this next season."
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Understand fashion calendar deeply. Build features for off-season (planning, sourcing). Diversify across brand types with different cycles.

failure_patterns.pattern: Underestimating enterprise fashion tech stack complexity
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Fashion enterprises use complex PLM (Product Lifecycle Management) systems. No integration = no adoption.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Pilots stall at "IT integration." Enterprise brands ask about Centric, Bamboo Rose, Lectra integration. Manual data entry required.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid:
Build PLM integrations early. Partner with PLM vendors. Understand enterprise fashion tech stack.

key_moves: Built AI that generated design variations from mood boards

success_stories.outcome_signal: Designers couldn't imagine working without it. Spread through design teams organically.

investor_questions.bad_answer: We have a lot of brands.
investor_questions.follow_up: What's your cohort retention by season?

investor_questions.question: What's the ROI for brands?
investor_questions.good_answer: 40% faster design-to-sample time saves $50-100K per season in sampling costs. Return rate reduction saves 2-3% of revenue. Typical mid-size brand sees $200K+ annual savings on $50K spend.
investor_questions.follow_up: Can you show ROI calculation for a real brand?

narrative_arc: Risk/compliance burden → AI-driven insight → regulatory approval → institutional trust

failure_patterns.pattern: Building without understanding financial regulations
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Financial services is heavily regulated. Wrong move = enforcement action, fines, shutdown.
failure_patterns.early_warning: "We're just a software vendor" without understanding implications. No compliance budget. No regulatory advisor.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Hire regulatory consultant early. Understand if you need registration (investment advisor, broker-dealer, etc.). Budget for compliance from day one.

failure_patterns.pattern: AI model without proper governance and validation
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Banks and asset managers have model risk requirements. Unexplainable AI = no adoption.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Can't explain model decisions. No model validation process. "It just works" when asked about methodology.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Build explainable AI from start. Document model methodology. Implement model governance. Third-party model validation.

failure_patterns.pattern: Expecting fast sales cycles at financial institutions
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Bank sales cycles are 12-24 months. Procurement, legal, compliance, IT security all must approve. You run out of money.
failure_patterns.early_warning: "We'll close banks in 6 months." No understanding of vendor risk assessment. Surprised by security questionnaires.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Plan for 18-month sales cycles. Build relationships 12 months before you need revenue. Understand bank procurement process.

failure_patterns.pattern: Showing returns without risk metrics
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Institutional investors evaluate risk-adjusted returns. High returns with high risk = not interesting.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Marketing absolute returns only. No Sharpe ratio, drawdown metrics. "Our AI beats the market."
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Always show risk-adjusted metrics. Benchmark against appropriate indices. Be conservative in claims. Show drawdown scenarios.

failure_patterns.pattern: 70%+ revenue from one financial institution
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Banks reorganize, change strategy, cut vendors. If your main client leaves, you die.
failure_patterns.early_warning: One client is most of revenue. Client relationship depends on one champion. Haven't diversified in 18 months.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid:
Set max client concentration targets. Always be building pipeline. Diversify across institution types (banks, asset managers, insurance).

key_moves: Reduced false positives by 60% vs rules
success_stories.outcome_signal: Banks couldn't pass audits without it. Compliance teams championed it.

success_stories.archetype: Better risk insights than internal teams
success_stories.pattern: Risk analytics → real-time monitoring → early warning → prevention
key_moves: Built risk models banks couldn't build internally
success_stories.outcome_signal: Paid for itself in prevented losses. Risk team expansion driver.

success_stories.pattern: Manual operations → automation → cost reduction → scale

narrative_arc: Financial friction/risk → regulated AI solution → trust + compliance → massive market

failure_patterns.pattern: Building product first, figuring out compliance later
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Banks and enterprises won't partner. Can't scale without licenses. One regulatory action can shut you down.
failure_patterns.early_warning: No compliance budget in seed raise. "We'll figure it out" when asked about licensing. No compliance advisor on team or board.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Budget 15-20% of seed round for licensing and compliance. Hire compliance advisor before launch ($150-250/hour for 10 hours/month). Map regulatory requirements for first 3 states before writing code.

failure_patterns.pattern: Building B2C fintech and relying on paid acquisition
failure_patterns.why_fatal: CAC is $50-200 per user. You can't outspend Chase, Venmo, or Cash App on marketing. You'll burn through your runway before hitting scale.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Relying on paid social/search for growth. No partnership or embedded strategy. "We'll go viral" without explaining how.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Build B2B2C or embedded finance model. Partner with platforms that already have your customers (payroll, HR, vertical SaaS). If B2C, you need a viral loop (social payments, referral rewards) or $20M+ runway.

failure_patterns.pattern: Building a single API or feature that Stripe/Plaid/banks could add
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Large players can copy features in 6 months. You have no moat.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Single API endpoint. No workflow ownership. "We're like Stripe but for X" (Stripe can build X). No proprietary data asset.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Own a workflow end-to-end, not just one step. Build proprietary data that improves with usage. Go deep in a vertical (construction payments, healthcare billing) where horizontal players won't follow.

failure_patterns.pattern: Spending 12 months building perfect infrastructure before getting customers
failure_patterns.why_fatal: You'll run out of money or build the wrong thing. Fintech has long build cycles—if you're wrong, you're very wrong.
failure_patterns.early_warning: No customer conversations in first 3 months. Building full ledger system before first transaction. "We need to be perfect before launch."
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Use BaaS to launch in weeks. Get 10 customers transacting before building your own infrastructure. Validate demand, then build moat.

failure_patterns.pattern: Relying on one sponsor bank or BaaS provider
failure_patterns.why_fatal: If they drop you (regulatory pressure, pricing change, acquisition), you're dead. Switching takes 6+ months.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Only one bank relationship. No backup conversations. BaaS provider is slow to respond or changing terms.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid:
Start backup bank conversations 6 months before you need them. Build to be bank-agnostic where possible. Diversify across 2 providers by Series A.

Positioned as the safe choice for enterprises
success_stories.outcome_signal: Enterprise customers chose them over faster-moving competitors because compliance was built-in. 3-month sales cycles instead of 12.

success_stories.archetype: Deep vertical focus before horizontal expansion

Launched lending based on payment history data (expansion, data moat)
Became the operating system for contractor finances
success_stories.outcome_signal: 3x revenue per customer after 18 months. Net retention >150%. Competitors couldn't match vertical depth.

success_stories.archetype: Powered financial features inside other platforms
success_stories.pattern: API → platform partnerships → reach millions without CAC
key_moves: Built clean API for embedding payments/lending into vertical SaaS
Targeted platforms with 10K+ SMB customers (HR software, property management)
Platform did all the customer acquisition
success_stories.outcome_signal:
Reached 50K end users through 3 platform partnerships. CAC effectively $0 (platform paid).

investor_questions.question: What's your take rate breakdown?
investor_questions.good_answer: Blended 2.3%. Interchange: 1.5%, platform fee: 0.5%, float: 0.3%. Cost basis: 0.8%. Net margin: 1.5%.
investor_questions.follow_up: What's your actual margin after interchange, processing, and fraud?

investor_questions.question: What's your CAC and payback?
investor_questions.good_answer: Blended CAC $340. Payback 8 months at $42/month margin. By channel: partnerships $180 (60%), paid $520 (25%), organic $90 (15%).
investor_questions.follow_up: How do you know this can be profitable?

investor_questions.question: Why won't Stripe/Plaid just build this?
investor_questions.good_answer: Stripe is horizontal infrastructure for developers. We own the entire AP workflow for construction—invoice OCR, lien waivers, job costing. We have 14 ERP integrations. Stripe would need 2+ years to build vertical software. That's not their model.
investor_questions.bad_answer: We move faster and care more.
investor_questions.follow_up: What stops them from copying in 6 months?

investor_questions.question: Who do you lose deals to?
investor_questions.good_answer: We lose to status quo (Excel) 40% of the time—our main competitor is inertia. When we lose to software, it's Bill.com (broader but generic) or doing nothing. We win when they need construction-specific features.
investor_questions.follow_up: What objections come up most in sales?

narrative_arc: Patient/provider pain → clinically validated AI → regulatory pathway clear → enormous market with strong barriers

failure_patterns.pattern: Building product without FDA/regulatory strategy
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Can't sell to health systems. Clinical claims without clearance = legal liability.
failure_patterns.early_warning: "We're just a wellness product" for something clearly clinical. No regulatory advisor. No FDA budget in raise.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Hire FDA regulatory consultant in first 6 months ($200-400/hour). Know your pathway: 510(k), De Novo, or exempt. Budget $200-500K for FDA process.

failure_patterns.pattern: Selling to clinicians when procurement decides (or vice versa)
failure_patterns.why_fatal: 18+ month sales cycles. Pilots that never convert.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Champions love you but "need to check with IT/procurement/compliance". Pilots stall after clinical validation.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Map the buying committee: clinical champion, IT, procurement, compliance, finance. Need 3-4 yeses. Start with buyer who has budget authority.

failure_patterns.pattern: Great product that doesn't fit payment models
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Health systems won't pay out of pocket for unproven ROI. Need CPT codes or value-based contracts.
failure_patterns.early_warning: "They'll pay because it's better" without reimbursement pathway. No one owns the savings you create.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Map who pays and how before building: existing CPT codes, bundled payment, shared savings, or direct license. Talk to payers early.

failure_patterns.pattern: Claiming AI accuracy without clinical validation
failure_patterns.why_fatal: One error = lawsuit, FDA action, reputation destroyed.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Claiming "99% accuracy" without peer-reviewed validation. Using ML benchmarks instead of clinical outcomes.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Clinical outcomes > ML metrics. Validate in real clinical setting. Publish results. Be conservative in claims.

failure_patterns.pattern: Entire health system deal depends on one person
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Champion leaves, deal dies. 40% of health system champions change roles within 2 years.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Only one contact at each account. Champion is doing "internal selling" alone.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid:
Build 3+ relationships at each account: clinical, IT, executive. Get executive sponsor above champion.

narrative_arc: Billable hour waste → AI matches human accuracy → dramatic time savings → confidentiality built-in

failure_patterns.pattern: Marketing "AI accuracy" without rigorous validation
failure_patterns.why_fatal: One wrong answer in legal = malpractice risk. Firms won't adopt unreliable tools.
failure_patterns.early_warning: No comparison to human baseline. Cherry-picked accuracy examples. "Results may vary" on everything.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Rigorous accuracy testing vs human experts. Publish methodology. Be conservative in claims. Show confidence scores.

failure_patterns.pattern: Building AI without enterprise security
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Law firms handle privileged information. One breach = career-ending for partners who approved it.
failure_patterns.early_warning: No SOC 2. "We use AWS so we're secure." No data residency options. Can't explain how model handles client data.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: SOC 2 Type II before selling to firms. On-premise or private cloud options. Clear data handling policies. Never train on client data without explicit consent.

failure_patterns.pattern: AI works on clean samples, fails on real firm documents
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Real legal documents are messy, scanned, redlined, multi-format. Demo accuracy ≠ production accuracy.
failure_patterns.early_warning: All demos use clean PDFs. First pilots have accuracy issues. "We need better document quality."
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Test on real firm documents (with permission). Handle scanned, redlined, multi-format from day one. Set realistic expectations.

failure_patterns.pattern: Selling to partners when innovation/IT decides (or vice versa)
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Law firms have complex buying. Partners control budget but IT controls security. Both must say yes.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Partners love it but "need to check with IT." IT approves but partners won't champion. Pilots stall at procurement.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Map the buying committee: practice group leader, innovation partner, IT security, procurement. Need 3-4 yeses.

failure_patterns.pattern: Building AI feature that iManage/NetDocuments will add
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Document management systems are investing heavily in AI. Point features get absorbed.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Your value is one AI capability. DMS vendors announce similar features. "Why not just use iManage AI?"
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid:
Own a workflow end-to-end (entire contract lifecycle, full discovery process). Build data moat from usage.

narrative_arc: Supply chain inefficiency → AI optimizes specific link → proven ROI → scales across network

failure_patterns.pattern: Product requires months of integration to show value
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Logistics operators won't wait 6 months. They need ROI in weeks.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Every pilot requires "custom integration." Engineering spends 80% on implementation. Time-to-value >90 days.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Build for major systems first (SAP, Oracle, Manhattan). Offer quick-start with data upload. Show value in 30 days or less.

failure_patterns.pattern: Building narrow tool that platforms will absorb
failure_patterns.why_fatal: SAP, Oracle, Blue Yonder will add your feature. You get acquired cheap or die.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Your value is one algorithm/optimization. Large vendors announce similar capability. Customers ask "why not just use SAP?"
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Own a domain completely. Build network effects (cross-company data). Go vertical (cold chain, hazmat, pharma).

failure_patterns.pattern: AI works on historical data, fails on live operations
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Logistics is real-time. Predictions that are 80% accurate cause 20% chaos.
failure_patterns.early_warning: All demos use cleaned historical data. First pilots have accuracy issues. Operations teams don't trust recommendations.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Validate on live operations before scaling. Build confidence scores. Start with decision support, not automation.

failure_patterns.pattern: Selling to IT when operations decides (or vice versa)
failure_patterns.why_fatal: 12+ month sales cycles. Pilots that never convert to contracts.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Champions love product but "need to check with ops/IT/procurement." Technical POC succeeds but no budget.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid:
Map decision makers: VP Operations, VP Supply Chain, CIO, Procurement. Need 2-3 yeses. Lead with business case.

narrative_arc: Manual creative bottleneck → AI-powered production workflow → faster delivery at scale → creative amplification

failure_patterns.pattern: Building editing feature Adobe will add to Lightroom/Photoshop
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Adobe owns professional photography workflow. They invest billions. Point features get absorbed.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Your feature is one Photoshop filter away from commoditization. Adobe beta has similar capability. "Better than Lightroom" is your pitch.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Own the workflow, not a feature. Build for specific verticals Adobe won't specialize in. Create data/network moat.

failure_patterns.pattern: AI editing that's fast but doesn't meet professional standards
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Professional photographers stake reputation on quality. "Almost good enough" = unusable.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Photographers manually re-edit AI output. Quality settings always maxed. "Good for rough cuts" but not finals.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Quality must be professional-grade first. Speed is secondary. Human-in-the-loop for critical decisions. Style matching must be perfect.

failure_patterns.pattern: Building editing tools without understanding pre-production
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Professional shoots are planned meticulously. Shot lists, storyboards, and creative briefs drive everything. Post-production is execution.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Users don't use your planning features. "We do that in spreadsheets/docs." Disconnect between planning and editing.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Understand full production workflow. Connect pre-production to post-production. Shot lists should inform editing.

failure_patterns.pattern: Building for enthusiasts who won't pay professional prices
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Hobbyist photographers have $10-20/month budget. Professional tools cost $50-500/month. Stuck in middle = bad economics.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Users love product but churn at $30/month. "Too expensive for hobbyists, not enough for pros." Low willingness to pay.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Choose: professional (high price, high value) or consumer (volume, low price). Don't get stuck in prosumer middle.

failure_patterns.pattern: Great editing, terrible asset organization
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Professionals have thousands of images per shoot. Finding, organizing, and delivering assets is half the work.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Users export to other DAM tools. "Where are my images?" complaints. No way to organize by project/client.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid:
Build asset management from day one. Projects, clients, deliverables, versions. Editing without organization = incomplete product.

failure_patterns.why_fatal: Every platform update = fire drill. Merchants blame you, not platform.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Customers report bugs after platform updates. Engineering spends 50%+ time on maintenance. No platform partner manager relationship.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Build on stable APIs, not hacks. Join platform partner program. Maintain test stores on beta versions. Budget 20% engineering for maintenance.

failure_patterns.pattern: Showing AI "potential" not actual merchant lift
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Merchants care about their P&L, not your demo data.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Sales uses demo store data. No case studies with real merchant numbers. "Results may vary" on everything.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: First 10 merchants = case study pipeline. Measure their actual lift. Publish real numbers (with permission).

failure_patterns.pattern: Building only for Shopify (or only WooCommerce, etc.)
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Platform concentration risk. If Shopify changes terms or builds feature, you're done.
failure_patterns.early_warning: 95%+ revenue from one platform. No roadmap for other platforms. "Shopify is big enough."
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid:
Multi-platform from seed stage. Core product, platform-specific adapters. Budget 30% of engineering for platform coverage.

failure_patterns.pattern: Building one AI feature that CRM will add
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Salesforce, HubSpot, and Microsoft invest billions in AI. They'll copy single features.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Your value is one prediction/automation. CRM vendors announce "AI" features. Buyers ask "why not just use Einstein/Copilot?"
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Own a workflow, not a feature. Build data moat from customer usage. Go vertical where CRMs won't follow.

failure_patterns.pattern: AI shows "potential" leads but doesn't actually convert
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Sales teams judge tools by closed revenue. "AI-scored leads" that don't close = turned off.
failure_patterns.early_warning: All demos use hypothetical data. No customer can show closed revenue from your leads. "Results are improving."
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Measure closed-won revenue, not lead scores. A/B test your leads vs their baseline. Publish revenue attribution.

failure_patterns.pattern: Deep integration that breaks with CRM updates
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Sales teams blame you for CRM issues. One breaking change = emergency support.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Support tickets spike after CRM updates. "Syncing issues" dominate support. No dedicated integration engineering.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Join platform partner programs. Test on beta releases. Budget 20% engineering for integrations.

failure_patterns.pattern: Tool helps management but annoys salespeople
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Sales reps are end users. If they hate it, they won't use it, and deals won't close.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Adoption is mandate, not organic. Reps call it "another admin task." Usage drops after first month.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Build for rep productivity first. Reduce their work, don't add to it. Measure rep adoption, not manager reports.

failure_patterns.pattern: "AI for sales" without specific use case
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Compete with everyone. No differentiated story. Hard to explain value.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Different customers have different use cases. "We do lots of things." Website is generic.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid:
Pick one use case: prospecting, forecasting, coaching, engagement. Own it.

narrative_arc: Platform fragmentation → AI-powered content adaptation → performance optimization → scalable social presence

failure_patterns.pattern: Business depends on single platform's API
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Platforms restrict access, change APIs, or build competing features without warning.
failure_patterns.early_warning: 90%+ value requires one platform API. No backup if access changes. Platform policy changes surprise you.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Multi-platform from day one. Build value that works without API. Maintain platform partner relationships.

failure_patterns.pattern: Optimizing likes/follows without business impact
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Brands pay for business outcomes (leads, sales, traffic), not vanity metrics.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Reporting focuses on followers/likes. Clients ask "but did we sell anything?" Can't tie social to revenue.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Connect social engagement to business outcomes. Attribution to conversions. Report metrics CFOs care about.

failure_patterns.pattern: Jumping on trends without brand alignment
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Random viral content doesn't build brand. Can even damage brand if off-message.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Content has no consistent theme. Brand voice varies wildly. Chasing every trend. "We're doing what's viral."
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Brand-aligned content strategy. Trend participation that fits brand. Consistent voice across platforms.

failure_patterns.pattern: Building B2B tools for creator economy
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Individual creators have $20-50/month budget. Need millions of creators for meaningful revenue.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Creators love product but won't pay $50/month. "Too expensive for me." Growth but no revenue.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Choose: creator volume (free/cheap tier) or brand focus (higher ACV). Or creator tools to reach brands.

failure_patterns.pattern: Scheduling without strategy integration
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Posting more ≠ better results. Content must align with campaigns, launches, events.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Tool used for scheduling only. Strategy done elsewhere. "We plan in spreadsheets, post here."
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid:
Connect content calendar to marketing strategy. Campaign integration. Cross-channel coordination.

success_stories.outcome_signal: Brands made better decisions with data. Strategy tool, not just posting tool.

investor_questions.question: What happens when platforms change APIs or policies?

investor_questions.question: How is this different from Hootsuite/Buffer?

investor_questions.follow_up: Can you quantify the performance difference vs scheduling tools?

investor_questions.question: Does engagement actually improve?
investor_questions.good_answer: Average 52% engagement rate improvement in first 90 days. Not from posting more—from posting smarter. AI identifies best content types, optimal timing, format adaptations per platform. A/B tested across 500+ accounts.
investor_questions.follow_up: Can you show before/after engagement data for real accounts?

investor_questions.question: What's retention like?
investor_questions.good_answer: 85% annual retention, 115% net revenue retention. Expansion from platform additions and team seats. Main churn: companies shutting down or cutting marketing entirely. Agencies: 92% retention because we're built into their client workflow.
investor_questions.follow_up: What's your 90-day activation rate?

narrative_arc: Fragmented bookings + operational chaos → AI unifies/optimizes → better guest experience + margins → network effects

failure_patterns.pattern: Building consumer travel app competing on marketing
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Expedia, Booking, Google spend billions on marketing. CAC is $50-200. You can't compete.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Relying on paid ads for users. "We'll go viral" without mechanism. No B2B or partnership distribution.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: B2B (hotel tools), B2B2C (white-label), or differentiated inventory (unique experiences no one else has).

failure_patterns.pattern: Business model depends on OTA commission structure
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Expedia/Booking change terms, you die. OTAs squeeze margins continuously.
failure_patterns.early_warning: 80%+ of bookings from single OTA. No direct booking capability. OTA is single source of inventory.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Build direct booking capability. Diversify across OTAs. Help suppliers reduce OTA dependency (that's a business).

failure_patterns.pattern: Product requires PMS integration, each one is custom
failure_patterns.why_fatal: 100+ PMS systems. Each integration takes months. You can't scale.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Each new customer needs custom integration. Engineering spends 80% on integrations. "We support 5 PMS systems."
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Build on integration platforms (Mews, Hapi). Focus on PMS families (Oracle suite). Or be PMS-agnostic with data upload.

failure_patterns.pattern: Travel company with no plan for seasonality
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Travel is 40-60% seasonal. If revenue drops 50% for 4 months, runway dies.
failure_patterns.early_warning: No corporate/business travel mix. 80%+ leisure. No counter-seasonal product.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Balance leisure + business travel. Build for year-round use cases. Plan cash for low season.

failure_patterns.pattern: Aggregating inventory before having travelers
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Inventory without demand = cost center. Suppliers won't stay exclusive without bookings.
failure_patterns.early_warning: "We have 10K properties" but minimal bookings. Suppliers ask "where's the volume?" High supplier churn.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid:
Demand-first: prove you can drive bookings before scaling inventory. Or B2B tools that don't require demand side.

success_stories.outcome_signal: Hotels couldn't operate without the tool. 95% retention. Expansion to adjacent products.

narrative_arc: Linear production bottleneck → AI-accelerated workflow → faster content delivery → creative scale

failure_patterns.pattern: Building editing feature that NLE vendors will add
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Adobe Premiere, DaVinci Resolve, Final Cut invest heavily. Point features get absorbed quickly.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Your feature is one Premiere update away from commoditization. Adobe beta has similar. "Better than Premiere" is your pitch.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Own workflow beyond editing. Build for specific verticals (corporate video, social content). Create data/network moat.

failure_patterns.pattern: AI that demos well but fails in production
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Video production has edge cases, client revisions, tight deadlines. Demo-ware fails under real conditions.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Works great on curated examples. Fails on real client footage. "Not ready for primetime" feedback.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Test on real productions early. Handle edge cases. Build for revision workflows. Reliability > features.

failure_patterns.pattern: Post-production tools without pre-production integration
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Video production is planned meticulously. Shot lists, storyboards, scripts drive everything. Disconnected tools create friction.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Users plan in other tools. Shot list features unused. Disconnect between planning and editing.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Connect pre-production to post. Shot lists should inform editing. Script-to-timeline features.

failure_patterns.pattern: Single-user tool in multi-person production
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Video production involves directors, editors, colorists, sound, VFX. Single-user tools create bottlenecks.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Projects shared via export/import. No review workflow. "We use Frame.io for that" frequently.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid: Build collaboration from day one. Review, comments, versions, handoffs. Integrate with Frame.io/existing tools.

failure_patterns.pattern: Tools for big productions applied to content creators (or vice versa)
failure_patterns.why_fatal: Feature film ≠ YouTube video ≠ corporate video ≠ social content. Workflow needs are completely different.
failure_patterns.early_warning: Product feels too complex for content creators or too simple for productions. "Not for us" feedback from target segment.
failure_patterns.how_to_avoid:
Pick a content type and nail it. Don't try to serve all video production. Depth in one segment > breadth.

decision_frameworks.decision: What part of workflow to own?

rows.if_condition: Your AI is best at analysis

investor_questions.question: How do you compete with Adobe Premiere/DaVinci?
investor_questions.good_answer: We're not an NLE—we augment them. Our Premiere panel automates rough cuts from shot lists, saving 4-6 hours per project. Editors still use Premiere for creative work. We're the production layer that connects pre-production to post. Adobe builds editing; we build workflow.
investor_questions.follow_up: What happens when Adobe adds AI editing features?

investor_questions.question: Does AI editing quality meet professional standards?
investor_questions.good_answer: Our AI handles technical work: syncing, assembly, format conversion. Creative decisions stay with editors. For rough cuts, 85% of AI-selected shots make final cut. We're not replacing creative judgment—we're eliminating tedious work.
investor_questions.follow_up: What percentage of AI work gets redone by editors?

investor_questions.question: Do production companies adopt for future projects?
investor_questions.good_answer: 78% project repeat rate. Productions that use us once use us for 4+ projects average. Key: we integrate into their existing Premiere/DaVinci workflow—no retraining. Time savings compound as teams learn the tool.
investor_questions.follow_up: What's your cohort retention by project count?

investor_questions.question: What's the ROI?
investor_questions.good_answer: Mid-size corporate video: 50% reduction in editing time, $2,000 saved per project. Production doing 20 videos/month saves $40K monthly. We charge $2K/month. 20x ROI. Plus faster delivery wins more clients.
investor_questions.follow_up: Can you walk me through ROI for a real production company?
